snippet.textDisplay: Still the highest critically rated fighting game of all time. While it's not my favorite in the genre, I did spend countless hours playing this awesome game on my Dreamcast. Visuals and gameplay completely blew me away. My Dreamcast definitely brought some good times and memories.
snippet.textOriginal: Still the highest critically rated fighting game of all time. While it's not my favorite in the genre, I did spend countless hours playing this awesome game on my Dreamcast. Visuals and gameplay completely blew me away. My Dreamcast definitely brought some good times and memories.

snippet.textDisplay: +SupraDarky yeah keyword :dreamcast...one of the most revolutionary games of all time and went perfectly with the time period. it had the fun factor of a nintendo console, and the edgy design and interface of a well sega console
snippet.textOriginal: +SupraDarky yeah keyword :dreamcast...one of the most revolutionary games of all time and went perfectly with the time period. it had the fun factor of a nintendo console, and the edgy design and interface of a well sega console

snippet.textDisplay:
+SupraDarky This game is not just awesome, it's amazing. One of my favorite fighting games, games on the Dreamcast and video games in general of all time. :D 

I remember when I was still in high school, I used to bring my Dreamcast to the class during parties and we played Soul Calibur the most and we were playing the living hell out of it. Good times.

Mind you, I had my Dreamcast since 2011, found at Goodwill for $20 (or something like that, I honestly don't remember. lol), it was in a box, came with a controller, a Jump Pack, a video input cable, an AC adapter, a phone cable, and the console itself. Although it did not came with any games, I had to wait till the next day to go to the antic store, the first games I got for the console were Sonic Adventure and Sega GT. For 1998 (in Japan), Sonic Adventure was definitely ahead of its time.
Nowadays I have over 80 games for the Dreamcast, with the rarest game I purchased is Cannon Spike (Yes I have a copy of Cannon Spike. lol). I honestly consider the Dreamcast to be superior than the N64, PS1, PS2, Xbox, the Nintendo Gamecube. Hell, I would rather play the Dreamcast over newer generation game consoles.
snippet.textOriginal:

I remember when I was still in high school, I used to bring my Dreamcast to the class during parties and we played Soul Calibur the most and we were playing the living hell out of it. Good times.

Mind you, I had my Dreamcast since 2011, found at Goodwill for $20 (or something like that, I honestly don't remember. lol), it was in a box, came with a controller, a Jump Pack, a video input cable, an AC adapter, a phone cable, and the console itself. Although it did not came with any games, I had to wait till the next day to go to the antic store, the first games I got for the console were Sonic Adventure and Sega GT. For 1998 (in Japan), Sonic Adventure was definitely ahead of its time.
Nowadays I have over 80 games for the Dreamcast, with the rarest game I purchased is Cannon Spike (Yes I have a copy of Cannon Spike. lol). I honestly consider the Dreamcast to be superior than the N64, PS1, PS2, Xbox, the Nintendo Gamecube. Hell, I would rather play the Dreamcast over newer generation game consoles.
